oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Two page photomontage of Nashville's funeral homes. Nashville Banner, 1927 April 17.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Gupton, L. A.; Sweeney, J. H.; Sweeney, A. Letty
Nashville Banner
Morgues & mortuaries
Nashville (Tenn.)--History--Sources; Nashville (Tenn.)--Social life and customs; Nashville and Davidson County (Tenn.)--History--Sources
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Two page photomontage of Nashville's funeral homes. Homes pictured include Crafton & Co. (610 Russell Street), M. S. Combs & Co. (Twenty-fifth Avenue North and Elliston Place), Sweeney Funeral Home (321 Woodland Street), Rains, Pettus, Burnette Company's Funeral Home (Elliston Place and Twenty-first Avenue), Wiles Brothers' Funeral Home (129 Eighth Avenue), Dorris Karsch & Company (Ninth Avenue and Commerce Street), Gupton Undertaking Company (215 Eighth Avenue South), Martin & Rollow's, Davis-Austin Company (1621 Broadway)and the National Funeral Home (209 Woodland Street). Of particular note are Wiles Brothers' and Rains Pettus, Burnette, both of which only employ white people/assistants and the National Funeral Home, which boasts Nashville's only lady undertaker. 16 x 21.5 in. Forms part of the Nashville Newspaper Rotogravure Digital Images Collection.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:publisher: Metropolitan Nashville/Davidson County Archives, Nashville Public Library
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:relation: Nashville Newspaper Rotogravure Digital Images Collection.
